items.content_html:
Fixes #32446

This modifies the Running server-side languages locally section in setting up a local testing server to make it clear that:

  • The right way to serve local files depends on what you're doing
  • If you're using a web framework that has a development server then using that server is probably the easiest approach for testing the code.
  • Otherwise you can use some other server, and it points out that http.server is an option. I don't know much about this, but there seems to be a fairly good tutorial in realpython, so I linked to that.
    • We could say more and separate out a section for this case if reviewers think that would be useful. The poster of the issue provided an example in the issue. I didn't want to make this document too heavyweight, because I think that most audiences for this doc will be using a web framework.
items.title: http.server is not limited to serving static files

items.content_html:
Description

Chrome 123 supports the field-sizing property, which is used to size textual form elements and textareas by their content, rather than sticking to a fixed size. This PR adds data for the new property.

  • ChromeStatus: https://chromestatus.com/feature/5176596826161152
  • Spec: https://drafts.csswg.org/css-ui/#field-sizing
  • Explainer: https://github.com/tkent-google/explainers/blob/main/form-sizing.md

Motivation

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests

  • BCD: mdn/browser-compat-data#22339
  • CSS data update: mdn/data#718
items.title: Add content to cover the field-sizing property

items.content_html:
Description

Added one new section explaining how url and base paths are merged; illustrated with four examples

Motivation

The simple but erroneous assumption that url and base are simply concatenated is a mistake easy enough to make.
Even if a developer is conscious about making an assumption and therefore cross checking by viewing the documentation he/she will not find the information on the page currently.
The documentation page should have a section or a note addressing this.

Additional details

RFC 3986

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: added section explaining path merging of url and base parameters

items.content_html:
Description

Chrome 123 adds support for the @media display-mode picture-in-picture value. This PR adds MDN content to cover this, both including the value in the display-mode reference page (and making it less PWA-centric) and including an example of usage in the document PIP API pages.

  • ChromeStatus: https://chromestatus.com/feature/5198101675769856
  • Spec: https://drafts.csswg.org/mediaqueries-5/#display-mode-picture-in-picture
  • Basic demo: https://document-picture-in-picture-api.glitch.me/display-mode.html

Motivation

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests

  • BCD: mdn/browser-compat-data#22321
  • dom-examples demo update: mdn/dom-examples#263
items.title: feat: editorial review: Add documentation for display-mode: picture-in-picture

items.content_html:
Description

Adds zstd Content-Encoding due to ship in Chrome 123

This also sets Brotli as a Standard since it's well supported in all major browsers so not sure why it was still marked as experimental.

Motivation

Support is about to ship in Chrome 123

Additional details

https://chromestatus.com/feature/6186023867908096
https://facebook.github.io/zstd/

Related issues and pull requests

BCD data here: mdn/browser-compat-data#22316
items.title: Add Zstandard (zstd) and mark Brotli as standard

items.content_html:
Description

#32360 contains the engineering technical review for my work on the Speculation Rules API docs Chrome 121 updates, which has been completed and approved. Thank you to @domenic, @kjmcnee, @tunetheweb, and @jeremyroman for your thorough and detailed review work.

This is a new PR based on the same branch, which is intended to contain the editorial review for the same work.

Background information

Chrome 121 has added several new features for the Speculation Rules API:

  • The Speculation-Rules HTTP response header, which allows developers to set speculation rules on a page via a response header, without modifying the actual page code. See https://chromestatus.com/feature/5069400512659456 for more info.
  • Document-sourced rules, which allow developers to specify a set of rules to include or exclude the URLs linked in the document in the list for prefetching/prerendering, rather than specifying an exact list of URLs. See https://chromestatus.com/feature/5112150536749056
  • The eagerness field, which allows developers to set how eagerly they want URLs to be prefetched/prerendered. See https://chromestatus.com/feature/5091678266851328.
  • The No-Vary-Search HTTP response header, which is used to indicate whether URL params should be ignored when deciding whether to fetch a page from cache or not. See https://chromestatus.com/feature/5071247189213184
  • The expects_no_vary_search field, which allows developers to report the expected value of the No-Vary-Search response header in the speculation rules, and use that to determine whether a prefetch would be beneficial or not. See https://chromestatus.com/feature/4887338302308352
  • The relative_to field, which allows developers to specify whether they want matched URLs that will have the speculation rules applied, matched relative to the document the rules are set on, or the file that contains the rules themselves.

Motivation

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: feat: Editorial review: Speculation rules Chrome 121

items.content_html:
The current description seems a bit misleading. As in reality if one sets a custom property to an invalid value, fallback won't be applied.

Example:

The following won't be resolved to 50px (even though 5yy is invalid and in theory, according to the current description should be used instead)

BUTTON {
   --vv: 5yy;
   font-size: var(--vv, 50px);
}

Using Cascading Variables: the var() notation

Guaranteed-Invalid Values

Description

Change in description to make it less misleading for developers.

I'm open to suggestions,
as the main point of the change is to make it more easily understandable than it is now, in my opinion.
items.title: var(): invalid v. undefined
